articles.headline: New Entry in E-Books Is a Paper Tiger
articles.snippet: Barnes & Noble’s e-book store has a lot of promise, but is saddled with filler, missing some top books and has some awkward details.
articles.abstract: Barnes & Noble’s e-book store has a lot of promise, but is saddled with filler, missing some top books and has some awkward details.
articles.lead_paragraph: Suppose there are two rival companies  let’s call them A and B. Each wants to dominate the blossoming world of electronic books.

articles.headline: After Clinton Trip, U.S. Studies Signals From N. Korea
articles.snippet: After former President Bill Clinton won the freedom of two American journalists, officials were busily calculating whether the psychology in Pyongyang had changed.
articles.abstract: After former President Bill Clinton won the freedom of two American journalists, officials were busily calculating whether the psychology in Pyongyang had changed.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  A day after former President Bill Clinton’s flight into North Korea to win the freedom of two American journalists, the Obama administration moved Wednesday to send a stern message to the North Korean government: nothing has changed.

articles.headline: For Today’s Graduate, Just One Word: Statistics
articles.snippet: With the explosion of digital data, statisticians can earn $125,000 in their first year after getting a doctorate.
articles.abstract: With the explosion of digital data, statisticians can earn $125,000 in their first year after getting a doctorate.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif.  At Harvard, Carrie Grimes majored in anthropology and archaeology and ventured to places like Honduras, where she studied Mayan settlement patterns by mapping where artifacts were found. But she was drawn to what she calls “all the computer and math stuff” that was part of the job.

articles.headline: Despite Bailouts, Business as Usual at Goldman
articles.snippet: Goldman Sachs executives are dismissive, even defiant, when critics argue that the bank is playing a heads-we-win, tails-you-lose game with American taxpayers.
articles.abstract: Goldman Sachs executives are dismissive, even defiant, when critics argue that the bank is playing a heads-we-win, tails-you-lose game with American taxpayers.
articles.lead_paragraph: Lloyd C. Blankfein has a story about the cataclysm that nearly brought down all of Wall Street. It goes something like this: One by one, lesser banks were swept away by the financial storm of 2008. And as the floodwaters rose, no one, not even Goldman Sachs, seemed safe.

articles.headline: 70 Murders, Yet Close to Going Free in Pakistan
articles.snippet: Justice in Pakistan is often derailed by intimidation and poor policing, leaving criminals free and witnesses fearful.
articles.abstract: Justice in Pakistan is often derailed by intimidation and poor policing, leaving criminals free and witnesses fearful.
articles.lead_paragraph: MULTAN, Pakistan  It has been 12 years since Fida Hussein Ghalvi testified against the militant who was charged with killing 12 members of his family. But some days he feels as if he were the one who ended up in jail. He still gets threats, his servants all quit and an armed guard is posted at his gate.
articles.byline: By Sabrina Tavernise and Waqar Gillani

articles.headline: Geithner Takes Regulators to Task on Turf Battle
articles.snippet: Treasury Secretary Timothy F. Geithner says regulators should not let relatively small disagreements kill the chances of passing a bill.
articles.abstract: Treasury Secretary Timothy F. Geithner says regulators should not let relatively small disagreements kill the chances of passing a bill.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  In what has become a routine spectacle, financial regulators went to Congress this week and raised objections to major portions of President Obama’s plan to overhaul financial industry rules.

articles.headline: U.S. to Reform Policy on Detention for Immigrants
articles.snippet: The plan aims to transform the detention system from a patchwork of jail and prison cells, and will review contracts with private companies.
articles.abstract: The plan aims to transform the detention system from a patchwork of jail and prison cells, and will review contracts with private companies.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Obama administration intends to announce an ambitious plan on Thursday to overhaul the much-criticized way the nation detains immigration violators, trying to transform it from a patchwork of jail and prison cells to what its new chief called a “truly civil detention system.”

articles.headline: Quick Tests for the Flu Found Often Inaccurate
articles.snippet: Widely used rapid checks for the H1N1 virus — or any flu, for that matter — fail more than 50 percent of the time.
articles.abstract: Widely used rapid checks for the H1N1 virus — or any flu, for that matter — fail more than 50 percent of the time.
articles.lead_paragraph: As the swine flu spreads, many doctors and hospitals are turning to rapid tests that can determine within minutes whether an anxious patient has the flu. Sales of such tests are soaring.
